title: Supreme Court to Consider State-Secrets Case Involving FBI Surveillance
sub_head: High court separately declines to hear case challenging male-only registration for the military draft
body:
WASHINGTON—The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to consider a U.S. government appeal that seeks dismissal of a case involving allegations of improper surveillance of Muslims, on the grounds that further litigation risks disclosing state secrets.
The high court separately declined to consider a sex-discrimination challenge to the longstanding requirement that only men register for the military draft when they turn 18 years of age.
In the surveillance case, three Muslim residents in Southern California filed a proposed class-action lawsuit alleging the Federal Bureau of Investigation paid a confidential informant to conduct dragnet surveillance of Muslims based solely on their religious identity. The suit, which dates back to 2011, claims an array of legal violations, including religious discrimination.
The plaintiffs allege the surveillance took place in 2006 and 2007, with an informant who, posing as a convert to Islam, infiltrated the Muslim community in Orange County and gathered personal information on hundreds of Muslims, including by surreptitiously recording people in mosques, homes and businesses.
The government hasn’t directly addressed many of the allegations, though the FBI has acknowledged it had a relationship with the informant. One FBI official in a court declaration said the government operation at issue aimed to prevent terrorist attacks and focused on fewer than 25 people.
